displaytitle: Decorative sculptures by the firm of Monduit et Béchet, Paris

makers.displaymaker: Charles Marville, 1816–1879; born and died Paris, France

texts.textentryhtml: Marville specialized in urban views, architectural records, and art reproductions for architects, designers, and city agencies in Paris. His clients included the firm of Monduit et Béchet, manu­facturers of metalwork architectural elements (including, in 1874, the Statue of Liberty). This ­photograph was displayed among the firm’s materials at the Inter­national Exhibition in London in 1862. The elements on view include figures from steeples Monduit et Béchet created in 1858 for two of the most important Gothic structures in Paris, Notre-Dame Cathedral and Sainte-­Chapelle. To show how the steeple ornaments looked in situ, Marville created rooftop views, which were widely disseminated at the time. Here, given the oppor­tunity to present the statues in more detail, he arranged a still life full of expressive visages. The result, doubtless gratifying to his client, looks as much like the inventory of a medieval church treasury as the product line of a modern foundry.

As the French government resolved to honor and preserve the nation’s architectural heritage in the mid-nineteenth century, the architect Eugène Emmanuel Viollet-le-Duc oversaw renovations of several Romanesque and Gothic churches. He relied on the firm Monduit et Béchet to produce metalwork, including a new spire for the Cathedral of Notre-Dame in Paris.

Marville documented these transformations to promote Monduit et Béchet’s metalwork, creating rooftop views to show the ornamental spires in situ, as in the above photograph of Notre-Dame. When given the opportunity to stage an elegantly lit composition of the firm’s wares at London’s International Exhibition of 1862, Marville arranged a still life of figural and ornamental elements. The result looks as much like the treasury of a medieval church, where precious and holy objects were stored, as the product line of a modern foundry.
texts.remarks: EUR1_02-05_WLA-Day 1 Cataloguing (group chat for x1994-57 and 2004-40)

texts.textentryhtml: The artist. [Acquired by Robert Koch Gallery, after 1978]; [purchased by Lee Gallery, Winchester, MA, 2000]; purchased by the Princeton University Art Museum, 2004.
